body:
Hi @danielblazevski, thanks for update and sorry for late reply. I tried to test your implementation and have found few things to do before merging this.

First, It is about test cases. I think we should add a test case for KNN with quad-tree rather than modifying a test case without quad-tree. Also we need some test cases with non-executable configuration such as KNN with quad-tree and non-compatible distance metric. A method to create a test case with exceptions is described in scalatest documentation (**Intercepted exceptions** section in  http://www.scalatest.org/user_guide/using_assertions).

Second, package definitions of `QuadTree` and `QuadTreeSuite` are not matched with directory structure.

Finally, I think we need to add more detail description with some mathematical background of KNN and quad-tree (including link of your slides and papers which you referred to) to the documentation. Also we need examples and  description of parameters with default value.

About rebasing, if you set `apache/flink` as remote `apache`, you can apply commands I suggested with renaming `upstream` to `apache`. You don't need to worry during rebasing. I also have copied branch of your `FLINK-1745` branch in my local machine. If you have some problems with rebasing, I'll rebase on `apache/master`.

@fhueske 
I was looking into the comments and the refactoring I can avoid by creating a new patch altogether. But seeing the last comment I think I can hold this off for some time. Felt sad as I wanted to bring this to closure. Anyway you are the expert so I need to adhere to your words here. No problem. Will check if I can take up some other JIRA or do you have any suggestions till then?
FLINK-3586 is created to track Long AVG issue.
The Memory tab in Java Mission Control can probably help with investigating this.
merging this PR
Thanks @ChengXiangLi for merging. The ASF bot only closes PRs which are merged into master. Can you close this PR manually? Thanks

Hi @ramkrish86, I totally understand that you are disappointed. I'm very sorry to raise these concerns this late after you put a lot of effort into this PR. I should have noticed this issue much earlier :-( 

Touching the optimizer is always a little bit like open heart surgery and must be done very carefully with the whole picture in mind. I have not completely investigated the possible side effects yet, but will definitely let you know once I have.

Would you like to work on a different issue in the meantime?

@fhueske 
Everthing is a learning. good that I got to know some flows out of this issue. Ya am interested to take up some other JIRA in the meantime.
If no objections I would like to merge this Friday morning.
Thanks for your PR! I'll look into whether loading the ExecutionConfig earlier breaks anything and then merge it.
Merging this.
Merging this.

I think that #1583 also addresses parts this, in a more generic fashion.
Reading the config earlier should not be a problem.

I would vote to get first #1583 and then from this pull request only the web frontend changes.
Ok, makes sense.
Merging this.
Merging this...
merging this.
Just a few misspellings. Otherwise looks great!
Thanks for the thorough review @vasia, that was quick :smile:

Very very very nice! Thanks for doing this! I like it a lot.

I was wondering whether we want to have a Scala version as well. What do you think? We can do it as a follow up if you don't have time for it now.

Thanks @uce as well! :smiley: 

I incorporated all the fixes. The only thing I'm not happy with is the section with the window. I feel that I can't do it without some small explanation but it also can't be to big/in-depth.

Scala I would do as a follow-up.
Alright, I merged it with the fixes.

Hi @chiwanpark, I modified the tests and corrected the package + import statements, please have a look.  

I will add more details soon regarding the description, math and slides

P.S. accidentally hit "close pull request" and then had to reopen

Hi @vasia this is a nice PR, I commented some minor documentation / naming issues
+1 for merging

Hey @s1ck,
thanks a lot for the thorough review! I will address your comments in the following days. The PR is quite old and needs a rebase, too.
For future reviews, keep in mind that it might be better to leave comments on the file diff of the PR instead of commenting on each individual commit. This way replying is easier, comments appear at one place, and the reviewer has the final changed view instead of the partial changes of each commit :)

I think the right way to solve that would actually not be in the MemoryManager (to cache), but in the operators that know that they will need the memory again and again and will hold onto it.

For another feature in the code, I am currently changing the access to memory such that it goes through "allocators". These are used by for example the sorter, to get their memory segments from the memory manager. It would be simple to create them in the batch operators such that they don't immediately release to the mem manager, but only after the operator is disposed. That means memory segments will be held onto through all iterations.
Ok, I will keep that in mind. Thank you!
Great work :+1:
@fhueske @ChengXiangLi  Can you please help me with review work? The error of CI build failure is not relevant.

I think the soft references solution is not worth investigating, and I agree that the best way to solve the problem is to make the operators smarter for the iterative jobs. Do you want to merge this pull request to temporarily solve the problem until the other solution is materialized? In case the answer is no, I think I might give this Jira back to someone else to be able to focus on serialization (in case the community accept me to work on that.)
Just a minor comment, mostly looks good to me. @fhueske , do you want to take a look at this PR?
passing the default to Operator.setParallelism() will result in an exception, intended?
Sorry, just removed right before you.

Thanks @gallenvara for opening the PR. Looks mostly good but the tests need to be improved, IMO.

It would also be good to extend the `DataDistribution` interface by adding a method `TypeInformation[] getKeyTypes()`. This will allow us to validate the key types of the `DataDistribution` and the specified keys in the `PartitionOperator`.
Thanks for the review @fhueske. I've addressed your comments.

build failure because of
- [FLINK-1445](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-1455) in [build job](https://travis-ci.org/apache/flink/jobs/114046004)
- [FLINK-3530](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-3530) see [log](https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/114046006/log.txt) in [build job](https://travis-ci.org/apache/flink/jobs/114046006)

[build job](https://travis-ci.org/apache/flink/jobs/114046008) fails because one of the newly added tests failed, will check and update the PR.

build failed because all jobs failed the `ClassLoaderITCase.testJobsWithCustomClassLoader` test.
I guess this is unrelated.
Yes, the test failures are unrelated. Looks good. Could you incorporate the last comments?

Our testing infrastructure is currently very unstable. Here is at least a build where everything passes: https://travis-ci.org/mxm/flink/builds/115046589

If nobody objects, I would like to merge the changes tomorrow.

Hey @s1ck,
thanks a lot for the valuable feedback. I've addressed your comments and rebased on the current master. Regarding the method renamings, I suggest we handle them in a separate issue.
I use actully `nc -l <port>` on Linux as well, so can we list that for both OS?
@fs111 Any updates here?
@tillrohrmann That true, in cases the tests are run individually.
Manually merged

+1, looks good to me

A minor "wish" from my side: I like it to not have generated files in the project directories, so I'd suggest to change the output file path to put the file into the "target" dir:

``` xml
<outputFile>${project.basedir}/target/scalastyle-output.xml</outputFile>
```
Merging this into the master (1.1.x) branch

This has been merged into master (1.1.x) and release-1.0 (1.0.x).

@mxm Can you close this? (was not autoclosed)

Looks good, the man page actually says:

```
-p source_port
   Specifies the source port nc should use, subject to privilege restrictions and availability. 
   It is an error to use this option in conjunction with the -l option.
```

I wrote that doc, but now I'm wondering how I came to use the `-p` option. I think we can just go with `-l`.
are there any objections to merging this? let's get this one in.

Thanks for the update @vasia.
Merged to `tableOnCalcite`. PR can be closed.
Thanks for finalizing and merging :)
Sure. Thanks for merging!

Great wish, my pleasure to grant it. :smile: 
Merging as soon as travis goes through.
@tillrohrmann The failures seem to be flaky, I've re-run them all on our fork and they're all green now (after a couple of retries).
Rebased on current `tableOnCalcite`.
I'll review the PR now
I tried finding updates to the documentation, but I couldn't find any (maybe its because of the PR size). We should at least add the new configuration parameters.
Tests are failing. I'll update the PR.

I tested the change on a secured CDH 5.3 setup and it worked, also across TaskManager failures:

Overall, the change looks good. I'm happy to see that the YARN tests haven't been touched much. As long as these tests are present, most of the features users need should work properly.
Also my tests on a secured virtual machine were successful.

I don't have the time to check in detail if all the message sequences and different procedures are implemented correctly but given that everything worked when I tested it, I'm positive that we can merge the change soon.

I think a quick review by @StephanEwen and @tillrohrmann would be good.

Thank you for working on this. I've been very busy with the 1.0 release, vacation and some talks, but now I'm back for my regular work.
I try to review the PR today or on Monday.
Changes look good to me! I only found 2 unused imports, but I can remove them before merging :)

Thank you for checking out the PR @rmetzger! Great to see it working in a cluster environment with Task Manager failures. I didn't add anything to the documentation (apart from JavaDocs) because this is an internal feature. It shouldn't affect the user apart form config parameters. I agree that these have to be documented exhaustively.
Any objections to merge this PR?
Thanks for the review @vasia . You want to merge it?
Yes, on it!
Going to merge w/o the distinction between Linux and OS X. Thanks for noticing this.

I didn't test the change on a physical, real distributed cluster. Only on a virtual machine from cloudera.
We should test the code on a real setup as well before merging.
Is this still a relevant PR with all the changes to the runtime in recent months? If not, can we close this?
Merged. You can close it!
With the recently introduced changes to the resource management in order to better be in line with Mesos' model, I think we can close this PR. Sorry!

This is dead. Everything has totally changed that this was based on. The fundamental problem is that this  is based on the assumption of the old 0.9 windowing code that events come ordered by time. The idea was to update the median incrementally when the current window changes, but the new windowing code is building several windows at the same time instead of windows gradually changing into each other, so I don't think that this idea could be adapted to the current version.
Anyone else wants to take a look at this PR or shall I go ahead and merge?

Test failures
- CheckpointNotifierITCase (2x) - known instability
- Kafka08 test

Looks good, merging this...
Good addition, merging this...

I think this is a useful tool. Few comments, though:
- You can still have a negative underflow (wrap around, positive) in the watermark generation.
- We have somehow reached the conclusion to use Guava as little as possible, potentially getting rid of it in the future.
- If the `extractWatermark(T, long)` and `getCurrentWatermark()` method should not be overridden, they should probably be final.

### About the name

I am not sure about the name, maybe a native speaker can chime in here. My git feeling was that this "trailing" would be understood as "event time trails by a certain amount behind processing time".

I used the term "max out of orderness" in the example in the documentation for the same case solved here: https://ci.apache.org/projects/flink/flink-docs-release-1.0/apis/streaming/event_timestamps_watermarks.html#timestamp-assigners--watermark-generators

What kind of exception do you get?

Also, subclasses of tuples that do not have additional fields can need not be Pojos (even though Tuples by themselves should actually meet the Pojo rules)

Regarding the stack trace of the Kafka test: the log shows two failures.
- The stack trace you posted is part of a test time out (that's why you have the interruption of the client in your stack trace), and
- a job restart when not enough task managers are connected (NoResourceAvailableException).

Looking at the code, the failures seem unrelated. Do you think that's not the case?

This pull request adds a lot of tests (which is actually good), but all tests fire up a cluster to execute many programs. But need to somehow get this down, as these "fire up mini cluster" tests have made our build times explode.

Is actual program execution needed here? Or is it sufficient to see that the partial function for a certain transformation creates such a transformation?
Merging this...

I just saw that you updated this pull request (actually a few weeks ago already)

A lot of it looks very good, some things we need to check a bit deeper (like how triggers actually behave on the two separate windows, how windows are matched).

Can you give a high level summary of how this should behave?
Especially given that you allow for custom triggers and window assigners here, how are windows matched against each other (to determine that their elements should be joined/co-grouped).
For tumbling time windows, the behavior is well defined and like discussed in the JIRA issue, but for generic windows and triggers, how is it defined?
merging this.
Thanks a lot!
Tests passed on my Travis.

I have started looking into this, but will need a bit more time...

Since there are already good sketches (in the attached PDF), it would be great to add these sketches to the "internals" docs, with a few lines of explanation. It might actually be interesting to a bunch of users...
Thanks, I removed backend changes

Hey @dawidwys, thanks for your contribution!
Your PR looks good besides some small comments. I think we can merge it, once they are fixed.
Glad I could help. I would also happily take on another issue regarding table API and SQL support if you could advise me some.
Hi @s1ck, thanks for opening pull request! I would like to change this link to "Contributing Code" (http://flink.apache.org/contribute-code.html) page rather than "Coding Guidelines". How about this?

Sounds good, but then I would change the text to:
`A detailed explanation can be found in our [Contribute Code Guide](http://flink.apache.org/contribute-code.html) which also contains a list of coding guidelines that you should follow.`

I went through the code. Couldn't find any issues.
+1 to merge from my side.

@dawidwys do you have any preferences? We have a long list of TODOs not all of them are represented in Jira issues so far. You can add more tests to verify Calcite rules, work on the Code generation or implement more Table API operators such as outer join or sorting.
Thanks for implementing my feedback. Looks good to merge. I will merge it later today if there are no objections.
@twalthr The Table API operators sound interesting. I will also gladly work on the Code generation. Frankly, the least fun would be tests for me.
will merge this today.
will merge this
